Author: dryicerx
Content:
Three possibilities depending on what the voices in your head are saying

- If they are random useless sayings: ignore them (see a doc)

- If they are good ideas : write them down

- If they tell you to do anything harmful: go see a doctor immediately

It's healthy to talk with your self in your head... like playing devils advocate and viewing the same problem/idea in different perspectives... but if it's unintentional, might be something else. Wish you best of luck.

Author: sidmitra
Content:
As a programming language Python would be more suitable, 'cos it's more generic.

When it comes to Econometrics or any other statistical analysis, you would probably call built-in/library/module functions to calculate things like Gini, Theil.

Most of these functions are available for python or even R. So you can learn the basic syntax for both, and figure out what is the best way to do what you need, as you go along.

Author: TJensen
Content:
More interesting to me (since Overstock.com and Traverse Mountain are nearby) was the linked article ( http://www.theregister.co.uk/2007/12/06/wikipedia_and_overst... ).

It is interesting to think about how much power the Wikipedia inner circle has over public dialogue. Wikipedia is often people's first stop when trying to find out about something new - if they show bias, it could change that dialogue significantly.

Author: patio11
Content:
I have a file we give our new (Indian) engineers prior to letting them work on projects for our (Japanese) clients.

It is called blue-pill.doc . (The official Japanese title of a similar document that existed a few years ago was Welcome To The Real World. I got to rename it when I was put in charge of it, and I like crosscultural puns.)

Bad news: while the number and identity of sounds in the Japanese language is widely agreed upon, there are two separate orderings on them which are in wide use, plus the "ABC order on the romanization" alternative which we see a bit of. (There are multiple plausible romanizations for many words, but we'll skip that discussion.)

Bad news: it is pretty hard to determine the pronunciation of a significant portion of Japanese algorithmically. You have to use a lookup table.

Worse news: there are multiple possible pronunciations of many Japanese words. It changes based on the context. This results in changing their lexical sort order... some of the time.

Still worse news: chunking natural Japanese text into individual words so that you can look them up is pretty hard, too. (For a taste of the fun, take any English sample document and remove all the whitespace, then tell me how you're going to pick words out.)

Bonus: Everything you know about Japanese lexical sorting is wrong for prefectures. The proper lexical sort is in order of geographic location, north to south. Don't ask why. It just is. Except when it isn't.

(Incidentally: I don't know what other companies do, but here, we put a display order column in all tables that routinely have contents displayed in order, and set the order manually. For things like names which customers can edit by themselves, we have them spell out the pronunciation as well if they want to do lexical sorting on it, otherwise we return the results in arbitrary order (on basis of code points, technically, but good luck explaining that to a non-technical person).

Why oh why did I not take the red pill. :)

Author: mattmaroon
Content:
That perception only exists among the sort of people who read this site. The other 99% of the populace doesn't think that deeply about it, and even if they did, they have a much more favorable opinion of Microsoft.

They started going to Google for whatever reason and stuck there because for many years it was light years ahead of the rest in terms of quality. Now it's going to take a much better search engine to top them. And if Microsoft made that engine, they could just leave it at live.com and grow (and at least it'd have the old 8% market share to start with). And if they don't, they can change the name every week and totally disavow any involvement but it still won't matter.

Author: jusob
Title: Please review my web application: http://safe.mn/
Content:
I wanted to address the two main criticisms to URL shorteners: security and transparency. Safe.mn creates a short link, but also performs extensive security checks on these links. Any link that is potentially harmful to the visitor gets flagged. When a visitor click on one of these flagged links, Safe.mn shows a warning (with a list of issues) instead of redirecting the visitor to the final URL. There are a few examples on the website that you can check: http://safe.mn/6, http://safe.mn/2, http://safe.mn/3

I'd like to get the feedback of the community: what sucks, what do you like, is is just another URL shortener for you do you see any additional value, etc.

I've just launched safe.mn, it is not complete yet. The biggest missing part is decent statistics. I'm already logging all the information, but I'm not displaying them yet. Let me know if you find anything else missing.

Author: jpeterson
Title: Ask HN: What to do about distracting mental chatter?
Content:
This is a bit strange, but somehow I figured I would find fellows among this crowd. For some time now, I've been experiencing what I would characterize as highly distracting and annoying dialogue going on in my head, out of my control. This goes far beyond the usual stuff that happens during e.g. debugging or any other puzzle-solving activity. There are various different disconnected voices, and they will constantly whisper, speak, and shout inanities. Oftentimes it's quite profane, and sometimes I catch myself unintentionally vocalizing it.

Does anyone else here face this? Have you found any remedy? Have I gone nuts?

Author: gojomo
Content:
Clearly some unicode is allowed, but I can't find a good reference as to whether all unicode characters are allowed, or whether each counts equally as one character against the 140-character limit.

But let's assume 140 bytes is the actual limit. That suggests around 255^140 possible tweets (assuming NULs unused). RFC678 defines a 'logical page' based on the printable area of a letter-sized page as 60 lines of 72 characters each; thus figuring 2 lines per tweet, that's 60 tweets per double-sided page.

So we need (255^140)/60 pages. An unopened ream (500 sheets) of 30lb paper I have is 5cm thick. So the stack of all printed tweets would be ((255^140)/60)×(5cm/500).

WolframAlpha calculates:

http://www86.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=((255^140)%2F60)*(5cm...

= 1.451x10^315 ly (light years)

...and they also helpfully offer a "Comparison as diameter"...

≅ 1.6x10^304 x diameter of the observable universe (≅ 93 billion ly )

So, even with an allowance for the smaller print of commercial publishing, there'd be no place in our universe to put this book. A Kindle version, implemented in a line or two of code, seems more practical.

ObBorges: http://jubal.westnet.com/hyperdiscordia/library_of_babel.htm...

Author: derefr
Content: A tweet is a zero-terminated string. It's 256^140, as the rest of the series can simply be unified with their representations padded with zeros.
